channel.title: Hypnosis
channel.description:
Do you think that hypnosis can cause physical effect on your body? such as vision enhancement, eye color changing, stopping alergic.
To add on, people with MPD has been reported to change eye color, having no allergies. while other personalities don't.

item.title: Hypnosis
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:14, topic:368736”]Yeah, don’t bother reading about activators.[/quote]“An activator is a DNA-binding protein that regulates one or more genes by increasing the rate of transcription.”

And because transcription has nothing to do about this, I don’t see how it relates?

Read full topic

item.title: Hypnosis
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Yeah, don’t bother reading about activators.

Read full topic

item.title: Hypnosis
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:11, topic:368736”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=464877.msg3402861#msg3402861 date=1290104455]
The only way your brain could do something like this was if you had chemicals already that could do these things (a chemical that removes allergies ), and the brain tells the chemicals to go into effect/turn on.
[/quote]As I said, I don’t know that it’s true in this example, but it sounds like a reasonable theory. The brain obviously causes the release of hormones all the time, so what’s stopping some of these proteins affecting DNA transcription?

en.wikipedia.org

DNA-binding protein

DNA-binding proteins are proteins that have DNA-binding domains and thus have a specific or general affinity for single- or double-stranded DNA. Sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins generally interact with the major groove of B-DNA, because it exposes more functional groups that identify a base pair. However, there are some known minor groove DNA-binding ligands such as netropsin, distamycin, Hoechst 33258, pentamidine, DAPI and others. DNA-binding proteins include transcription factors which...


en.wikipedia.org

Activator (genetics)

A transcriptional activator is a protein (transcription factor) that increases gene transcription of a gene or set of genes. Most activators are DNA-binding proteins that bind to enhancers or promoter-proximal elements. Most activators function by binding sequence-specifically to a DNA site located in or near a promoter and making protein–protein interactions with the general transcription machinery (RNA polymerase and general transcription factors), thereby facilitating the binding of the genera...


etc

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=464877.msg3402861#msg3402861 date=1290104455]
The brain itself has no control over how your DNA/cells replicate, it’s all done in the cell itself.
[/quote]Yes, DNA replication is done in the individual cell. Transcription != replication.[/quote]Because that’s not how transcription works…

en.wikipedia.org

Transcription (biology)

Transcription is the first step of gene expression, in which a particular segment of DNA is copied into RNA (especially mRNA) by the enzyme RNA polymerase. Both DNA and RNA are nucleic acids, which use base pairs of nucleotides as a complementary language. During transcription, a DNA sequence is read by an RNA polymerase, which produces a complementary, antiparallel RNA strand called a primary transcript. Transcription proceeds in the following general steps: The stretch of DNA transcribed into a...

Read full topic

The brain obviously causes the release of hormones all the time, so what’s stopping some of these proteins affecting DNA transcription?

en.wikipedia.org

DNA-binding protein

DNA-binding proteins are proteins that have DNA-binding domains and thus have a specific or general affinity for single- or double-stranded DNA. Sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins generally interact with the major groove of B-DNA, because it exposes more functional groups that identify a base pair. However, there are some known minor groove DNA-binding ligands such as netropsin, distamycin, Hoechst 33258, pentamidine, DAPI and others. DNA-binding proteins include transcription factors which...


en.wikipedia.org

Activator (genetics)

A transcriptional activator is a protein (transcription factor) that increases gene transcription of a gene or set of genes. Most activators are DNA-binding proteins that bind to enhancers or promoter-proximal elements. Most activators function by binding sequence-specifically to a DNA site located in or near a promoter and making protein–protein interactions with the general transcription machinery (RNA polymerase and general transcription factors), thereby facilitating the binding of the genera...


etc

[quote=“Davidi2, post:9, topic:368736”]The brain itself has no control over how your DNA/cells replicate, it’s all done in the cell itself.[/quote]Yes, DNA replication is done in the individual cell. Transcription != replication.

Teh Spede:

My cells do not contain domain name servers

Apparently so, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA-binding_domain

Read full topic

item.title: Hypnosis
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:8, topic:368736”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=464877.msg3402601#msg3402601 date=1290069175]
Hypnosis works with the brain

Your cells contain DNA that gives them the information about how to replicate themselves, the brain doesn’t change your DNA.

All hypnosis does is ‘talk’ to your subconsciousness, and sometimes give you a push in the right direction toward one of your goals. However: hypnosis can not make you do something you would not normally do.

tl;dr - No.
[/quote]
Genetic expression is a lot more complex than just ‘having’ DNS. The presence of certain substances can allow certain chunks of DNA to be transcribed, without actually changing it. I’m not saying that I know hypnosis can do this, but it’s pretty close minded to assume the brain and the rest of your body are completely unrelated.[/quote]The only way your brain could do something like this was if you had chemicals already that could do these things (a chemical that removes allergies ), and the brain tells the chemicals to go into effect/turn on. The brain itself has no control over how your DNA/cells replicate, it’s all done in the cell itself.

Read full topic

item.title: Hypnosis
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:7, topic:368736”]Hypnosis works with the brain

Your cells contain DNA that gives them the information about how to replicate themselves, the brain doesn’t change your DNA.

All hypnosis does is ‘talk’ to your subconsciousness, and sometimes give you a push in the right direction toward one of your goals. However: hypnosis can not make you do something you would not normally do.

tl;dr - No.[/quote]
Genetic expression is a lot more complex than just ‘having’ DNS. The presence of certain substances can allow certain chunks of DNA to be transcribed, without actually changing it. I’m not saying that I know hypnosis can do this, but it’s pretty close minded to assume the brain and the rest of your body are completely unrelated.

Read full topic

All hypnosis does is ‘talk’ to your subconsciousness, and sometimes give you a push in the right direction toward one of your goals. However: hypnosis can not make you do something you would not normally do.

tl;dr - No.
